sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying helix
message_1: A current-carrying helix has 200 turns, a diameter of 4 cm, and a length of 20 cm. The current through each turn is 2 A. Calculate the magnetic field at a point on the axis of the helix, which is at a distance of 8 cm from the center of the helix.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at a point on the axis of the helix, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a solenoid:

B = μ₀ * n * I

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), n is the number of turns per unit length, and I is the current through each turn.

First, we need to find the number of turns per unit length (n):

n = total number of turns / length of the helix
n = 200 turns / 20 cm
n = 200 turns / 0.2 m
n = 1000 turns/m

Now, we can calculate the magnetic field (B) inside the solenoid:

B = μ₀ * n * I
B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A) * (1000 turns/m) * (2 A)
B = 8π × 10^(-4) T

The magnetic field inside the solenoid is uniform, so the magnetic field at a point on the axis of the helix, which is at a distance of 8 cm from the center of the helix, is the same as the magnetic field inside the solenoid:

B = 8π × 10^(-4) T ≈ 2.51 × 10^(-3) T

So, the magnetic field at the given point is approximately 2.51 × 10^(-3) T.
